answers.answer: Your dad could consider keeping a few teeth if he wants to even though multiple dentists have recommended removal of the teeth.  The problem with keeping them though is that if there is a problem, it may interfere with the dentures and make it more difficult to fix.  Also, if the teeth are in bad shape, it indicates there is either a low grade chronic infection or the potential for an acute infection to occur, therefore putting more stress on his body.  Bad gum disease is associate with a wide range of health problems.

question: My 86 yr old diabetic Dad is reluctant to extract his remaining 5 upper front teeth even after advised by 4 different dentists. One dentist said he has to get bone grafting. Another said dont bother with bone grafting because it will take too long and he has diabetes and needs dentures to eat, and implants will take too long. But my Dad really wants them. Dad insists his rotted discolored remaining 6, 7,8,9,10 are strong and imbedded well even though 2 of them are worn down to the gum base. Can one or 2 of his front uppers remain and 2 implants be installed on the upper worn out ridge and just experiment ASAP and if it doesnt work, we can pull the rest of the front teeth later? But at least he can begin to eat sooner than 90 days for extractions to heal?His upper ridge is very high but the front is lower. The CT scan shows he has enough space for implants to just clear his sinus.
title: Bone grafting for diabetic 86 year old
